title: What can be gained by making a reboot of 'The Princess Bride' movie? - Quora

response.answer_text: A remake of “The Princess Bride”, "inconceivable"… The Princess Bride is a 1987 American fantasy adventure comedy film directed and co-produced by Rob Reiner, starring Cary Elwes, Robin Wright, Mandy Patinkin, Chris Sarandon, Wallace Shawn, André the Giant and Christopher Guest. Adapted by William Goldman from his 1973 novel The Princess Bride. One of the few movies where they did just about everything right, for once. The author of the book wrote the screenplay. Rob Reiner, from ‘All in the Family’, was director, and a perfect cast, like Robin Wright as Buttercup, Andre the Giant as Fezzik (a giant), Wallace Shawn as Vizzini, a mastermind criminal bully. Peter Falk as Grandpa/The Narrator. Fred Savage as The Grandson. Nothing can be gained by making a reboot of "The Princess Bride" movie, except maybe making more money, But I doubt it will do as well as the original, so it would just be a terrible waste of their time and money.

Is some idiot really imagining that a remake of Princess Bride is possible or desirable? What a waste of money — like the remake of Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, with Johnny Depp replacing Gene Wilder. Nobody wanted it, and almost everybody thinks of the Gene Wilder version as the “real” one. Even if some wonderful current actors are in a new Princess Bride, it won’t help. Nothing will make us forget the splendid casting and acting in William Goldman’s script and story. Some remakes work — but only if they make large changes. Shop Around the Corner was a wonderful movie; You’ve Got Mail was a remake, but it was a completely new, updated script, so that you can watch the two movies back to back and enjoy both parts of the double feature. The one doesn’t REPLACE the other; it’s merely an echo, with much new material to delight us. But Princess Bride just does NOT need a reenvisioning. The delicate balance of humor and romance in Princess Bride is perfect, and any changes are likely to be fatal. Even a parody would probably not work — Rebel Wilson as Buttercup would have her delights for us, but it would wear thin long before the movie ended. Since Princess Bride IS a satire, satirizing it would be absurd. The movie exists. It is perfect as it stands. Even its flaws are part of its perfection. I hope they leave it alone. If they actually make such a badly conceived project, I won’t be attending it. Because life is short.
